text: to be fair, it is a good reminder. you can never have too many reminders to make sure you've saved (and backed up) your data!
this is what happens when i'm trying to multi-task wedding planning and being a grad student.
thanks. i appreciate your attempts to help (despite the fact that they were blocked!)

today i had a miserable experience giving a presentation. despite this, i really appreciate the support of my fellow grad students. nodding & smiling, giving supportive comments, & genuinely trying to keep things positive. i’m grateful to be surrounded by such great people!

just echoing this. i had a similar trajectory. my worst semester was my junior year. i did a post-bacc once i was ready but it is possible if it's what you really want. it is also perfectly fine to change your mind about med school. you can do this!

tip for mentors: the best time to tell a student what they are doing wrong in presentations is not immediately after they finish a stressful presentation. yes, critical feedback is important but sometimes we need a minute to breath before being told everything we did wrong.
i'm near ann arbor!

it's not a big deal, the other data i needed but this was more about making a point so doesn't really matter. i feel like this is something someone must have written about since it connects with dih laws, so i was wondering if anything came to mind, no need for additional work!

of note, the data i provided were correct but as a lowly med student i could not say that at the time as i had nothing to back myself up with. i really appreciate the experts of twitter taking the time to confirm & clarify these issues with me so i can confidently respond.

okay, that makes sense, thank you. so, to my rather crude analogy, there is not a drug-induced homicide equivalent for alcohol in the context of friends "supplying" each other with alcohol (in most states at least)?

bad: being only med student in room of physicians & policy experts & told the data/examples i provided were false w/o being able to argue. good: asking twitter for help verifying facts & receiving fast, helpful feedback & clarification from experts in the field. thank you!

follow up somewhat related q (if you don't mind): i'm aware of laws that allow prosecution of those who sell alcohol (e.g. bartender) to an adult who becomes overly intoxicated & dies but do you know whether those laws would apply in a private setting (e.g. a dinner party)?

ah, that is much clearer, thank you both! it was very frustrating b/c i was told (by a legal expert) that i had provided false information about this but i was pretty certain i had not so i appreciate the clarification here.
i mean gsl protections for someone who was using drugs with a person who overdosed & died despite that person calling for medical help.

i'm having trouble because the  report on dih laws says that "the only states that provide immunity for drug-induced homicide if a person seeks medical assistance are vermont and delaware" but i cannot find anything to confirm that for vt. http://www.drugpolicy.org/sites/default/files/dpa_drug_induced_homicide_report_0.pdf

looking for some help from drug policy people. a legal expert told me that there are no states offering good samaritan-like protections from drug-induced homicide charges but i thought delaware & vermont did. anyone have the actual policy for this that i can provide?

i think i’ve found the most passive aggressive way to get the last word in: 1) start argument via email 2) follow up immediately with “do not reply, i’m under the care of a cardiologist & need calm” not the nicest thing to wake up to though.
you put my feelings into words, thank you! i had been trying to find a way to explain how i was feeling about this and you completely got it.
and obviously by starts i meant stops. clearly my thoughts were distracting me.
it's singing for me. not that i sing well, but if i'm singing along to music the inner monologue starts. i can't think and remember the words to songs at the same time.
haha, i had this exact same response when tony told me that he didn't have thoughts & words in his head. i was so confused. i still can't imagine anything else!

this mindset is pervasive & ridiculous. i have a large support system, the means to get to doctor’s, & ability to miss work if needed & i’ve had trouble making appointments. i can’t imagine how hard it must be for someone without these levels of support. we need to do better.

today i tweeted about a new leadership position; however, yesterday i chose not to apply for a position i wanted w/ a great group. both of these things are worth celebrating! the ability to recognize our needs & put ourselves first is more important than a new title/project.
thanks bri, i am grateful for all the support! i am looking forward to working more closely with physicians and students of the  and representing the student section to the bod over the next year.

as i start preparing for quals & reading a lot of different papers i am having trouble finding a good way to keep track of everything i read & the key points of each paper. at the moment i just have a word doc but it's messy. how do you keep track of what you've read?

from my knowledge of the 2 drugs i am inclined to agree. my objective with this slide was not to say that these are the definitive, objective harms of each drug listed; rather, i want to illustrate the point that legality is not representative of potential for harm.

it is worth noting that i am using these data in an effort to illustrate the point that the legality of a drug is not usually representative of its potential for harm. i am not attempting to state that these are the definitive, objective harms for each of these drugs.

that is the way the chart reads, yes. you can see in the fig on the left how the harms were defined and read more about the process in the study the graph is from: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/piis0140-6736(10)61462-6/fulltext it is worth noting this study was published in 2010.

the cited study explains the rationale for the fig, and the slide also shows what types of harms were evaluated. the purpose of the slide is not to state that these are the 100% correct scores for each drug but to help student re-evaluate the belief that legality represents harm.

definitely very subjective. it's part of why i included the characterizations of harm in the slide. i wanted to start a discussion about the harms that were chosen & get people thinking about the different ways of characterizing harm.
of course! for things like this i like to make sure the title of the paper & authors are very visible on the slide.
that's a great idea, i wonder if the med school would do something like that. thanks for sharing this one!
to clarify, the figures themselves come from the paper referenced, but i added the arrows & numbers onto fig. 2 to illustrate the current drug laws and scheduling in the usa.

a medstudent just told me that the legality of a drug represented how harmful it was (amongst a whole host of other misconceptions about drug use). clearly, the best response was to spend my morning adding data to my presentation for next week. i'm pretty happy with this slide!
*this reminder brought to you by the presentation i worked on all morning rather than the 5 other things that have more pressing deadlines.

reminder for anyone who needs it: give yourself credit for whatever task you are able to complete. maybe you wanted to do something else or do more but try to focus on the fact that you were able to do something.
i have 3 presentations that i need to prepare & present over the next month, so naturally i am working on the presentation i have to give in may.
“when it comes to advocacy, if you don’t do something then no one will” - dr. sarah pickle membersmovemedicine
thank you! it was a great session with so many new policy ideas & collaborations forming. region 5  are always working hard to develop new policies! membersmovemedicine

the majority of bills that impact patients will not have input from physicians. we need to be advocates to make sure that only accurate, evidence-based policy is passed. - dr. sarah pickle discusses the need for physicians to advocate for their patients. membersmovemedicine

some fantastic tips from  on advocacy: 1) find & capitalize on your strengths 2) find your purpose - know why & how you’re doing what you’re doing 3) connect the dots - make sure the work you’re doing is related 4) be inspired 5) thank people at every opportunity
“advocacy shouldn’t be about you” fantastic talk from  about engagement in advocacy & how to be a strong advocate at the region 5  conference.
also, i am not a fan of the “tobacco user” language but that’s a whole different problem.

a friend of mine sent me this med school question. it’s a “select all that apply” question & i’m confused as to how that’s enough info to know the answer. what are we missing? note: the selected answers are not necessarily correct.

from this picture you’d think this cat was adorable & sweet, but it’s all a lie! this is him in my spot. i took my spot back, and sat down with a snack. he glared at me & then sneezed directly into my food. i am certain he knew what he was doing.
i take my shoes off while i'm in my seat but always put them back on before moving around the plane. also, i always wear socks on the plane so people don't have to look at my bare feet!
yes, i’ve flown to mexico & canada (and domestically) with my naloxone in my carry on bag. not had a problem so far.

yes, there does seem to be a lot of variability in the data. one of the points this speaker made is that certain pharmacotherapies may only be effective for specific sub groups of people with stimulant use disorder, which could partially explain the reproducibility issues.
important point from : you can’t expect one simple molecule (i.e. ioat) to solve the decades long problems caused by poverty, discrimination, & trauma. aaap30

we need to open up our policy discussions & think outside the box. increasing access to treatment must be a priority but there are other harm reduction options that we can consider even if it’s just on a temporary basis -  aaap30

we need a lot more research on supervised consumption sites and we need to look at outcomes other than just death & disease. how do these sites impact stigma, treatment seeking & other related outcomes? -  aaap30

major recs from report on heroin assisted treatment (hat) from  1) it should be legal to research schedule 1 drugs 2) we must develop hat randomized control trials in the usa 3) hat locations should provide a wide range of services, including methadone. aaap30
this is so important. we can’t talk about what our patients need unless we actually ask them & involve them in these conversations as well as the research & policy decisions. aaap30

the main goal of heroin assisted treatment (hat) is to reduce illicit heroin use & help stabilize lives. patients usually receive hat under medical supervision & it can help connect them to healthcare -  aaap30
clients report a wide range of benefits associated with receiving injectable opioid agonist treatment (ioat), we need to maintain a focus on patient centered care -  aaap30
a review of the differences between supervised consumptions sites (scs) and injectable opioid agonist treatment (ioat) from  aaap30
the data & the science are important but at the end of those data are people and they are critical. we must always put our patients first.  aaap30
supervised consumption sites & injectable opioid agonist treatment are complementary but different approaches to engaging people into the healthcare system -  aaap30
we need to develop a sustainable, long-term infrastructure for responding to these problems rather than just jumping from crisis to crisis -  aaap30

“we need to make sure that the solutions we put forth are not middle class solutions” -  these solutions need to be accessible to everyone, regardless of their income level & access to transport. aaap30
we are reminded by  of the urgent need to improve access to treatment for opioid use disorder. we need to do what we can to advocate for the removal of barriers to care. aaap30
important reminder from  to be aware of the language we are using & to work to educate others, both physicians and community members, on the use of accurate & non-stigmatizing language. aaap30
call to action from : if we see a problem that impacts our patients & their access to care, we must do what we can to make changes. aaap30
we know that there isn’t one sole solution to the opioid crisis & we need to work together.  shares the recommendations of the  opioid task force recommendations. aaap30

first up this afternoon is ama president  talking about the ways that we can work to change policy regarding addiction. we need to fight for the issues that affect our patients. aaap30 membersmovemedicine

it is important to remember that prep doesn’t become effective at preventing hiv immediately. dr. moore points out that people who inject drugs should be aware that it takes about 3 weeks to become effective in the blood. aaap30

important guidelines on when to discuss prep with patients. dr moore also includes patients who may be experiencing intimate partner violence and those who have recently been diagnosed with syphilis as they are at higher risk of developing hiv. aaap30
when taken as prescribed prep gives patients the choice & agency to protect themselves from hiv on their own terms - dr. moore aaap30

at current rates of transmission, people who inject drugs have a high risk of hiv diagnosis. addiction psychiatrists can play a major role in reducing hiv transmission through prescribing prep to patients at high risk. aaap30

helpful tips for sexual history taking from dr moore at aaap30 : - make no assumptions - recognize patient anxiety - talk less...listen more - recognize your own biases - avoid value laden language - “fix your face!” (make sure you appear open & non-judgmental)

dr moore is starting his session on how to take a good sexual history. this is so important. a physician’s comfort taking a sexual history plays a major role in the patient’s comfort & willingness to be open with their provider. aaap30

i’m really looking forward to this next session with dr leo moore, who will be discussing best practices for addiction psychiatrists prescribing pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) to prevent hiv transmission in people who use drugs. aaap30
the initial data suggests that the people prescribed these medications for this purpose were taking them only in the way prescribed by the physician.

dr levin tells us about medications that have efficacy for cocaine & stimulant use disorders. we need to be aware that different medications will work for different people depending on their phenotype. the ones in green have been studied in over 100 patients. aaap30
she cites this study that shows that sustained releases dexamphetamine improved outcomes and reduced cocaine use in patients receiving heroin assisted treatment for opioid use disorder. aaap30

dr. frances levin is discussing pharmacological treatments for cocaine/stimulant use disorder. she points out that we already have agonist medications (dextroamphetamine) that seem to be effective, so why are we not using them? aaap30

dr. john mariani points out that while we are seeing increases in cocaine & stimulant overdose deaths, many of those people also had fentanyl in their system (red portion of the bar graph). how can we determine which drug was responsible for the death? aaap30

dr. larissa mooney reminds us that it is okay to change our minds about a particular issue. being a good advocate does not mean being inflexible. we need to remain open to new information & evidence. aaap30
grateful for the reminder from dr james berry that substance use disorders are psychiatric disorders; we can’t separate mental health from substance use disorder treatment. aaap30

advice from  ceo kathryn cates-wessel: advocacy can be more powerful & effective when accomplished in a group. we can’t be the best at everything so we should collaborate with people who can do it better. aaap30
shout out to the  and president  at the  session on advocacy in addiction psychiatry. the ama and state societies provide important avenues & training for advocacy! aaap30 membersmovemedicine
great advocacy advice from dr elizabeth howell: advocacy allies may be unexpected. you don’t have to agree on all the issues but you can bond over shared goals. aaap30

the general public typically only sees the negative news stories about substance use disorders. it is our responsibility as experts in the field to go out and make it clear that suds are diagnosable & treatable & to share the positive stories. aaap30
important point in the  advocacy session: it is the responsibility of the communicator to be understood. we have to make sure that what we’re saying is clear & easy to understand. aaap30

so often i hear career advice that says we need to focus on one topic otherwise people will assume we aren’t dedicated to anything. i really like that this aaap30 panel is advocating for diverse interests & discussing how much this can improve our understanding & our work.

i love that the  trainee guide to addiction fellowship speakers all talk about non-linear career paths & the opportunities they did not receive. so often it looks like people take direct paths to their amazing careers but most of the time that isn’t the case. aaap30

some great advice at the  trainee workshop: 1. seek out good mentors 2. say yes to things (but you don’t need to say yes to everything!) 3. it is okay to change your mind, if something isn’t working for you then make a change. aaap30

just telling a patient with a substance use disorder who is seeking help for physical or psychological symptoms to “stop using the drug” is not helpful. please let’s stop discussing this as a legitimate intervention.
patients who receive gastric bypass surgery may be at increased risk of developing alcohol use disorder due to increased levels of the hormone ghrelin 6 months post surgery- dr. elie aoun aaap30

research presented by dr schmidt shows that estrogen levels are associated with increased substance use & progesterone levels may be associated with decreased craving & increased success when abstaining. this provides important insights for treatment of suds. aaap30

interesting start to the session on neuroendocrine targets for suds at . dr kristen schmidt discusses sex differences in substance use. women escalate use faster than men & develop organ damage earlier. this is something we should be talking to patients about. aaap30

great session by dr. ritu bhatnagar & colleagues on the effect of patient overdose deaths on providers & ways to improve training to provide tools to reduce burnout for people working in addiction medicine. aaap2019 aaap30
i’m excited to be in sunny san diego for the aaap2019 meeting! already heard a fantastic first session about treating youth with oud & i’m looking forward to more great sessions.

also, since some of you have been trying to purchase naloxone, i would love to plug my survey on people's experiences obtaining naloxone. we are looking to find out more about everyone's experiences trying to get naloxone!

i don't know about pharmacies but a lot of state & county health departments distribute naloxone for free. when buying from a pharmacy, some insurance companies may cover the full cost or at least a significant portion of it and in some states medicaid may fully cover it.

absolutely phenomenal harm reduction workshop at amersa2019. thank you to everyone involved in organizing this. i’m looking forward to implementing some of the strategies we discussed at my own institution!
fantastic audience point: when we’re talking to people who use drugs it is important to ask them what they like about the drug & why they use it. amersa2019

reminder that no matter how many workshops we attend, most members of the healthcare team are not going to be experts in injecting drugs so we must defer to the patient’s knowledge & talk through their process with them. amersa2019
some people who inject drugs need others to inject for them. it can be an important & powerful form of self-liberation to teach them how to inject drugs themselves - dr. joseph wright amersa2019

in the workshop on harm reduction education. when we talk to patients about how to use drugs more safely rather than nagging them to stop using drugs it drastically improves the therapeutic relationship. amersa2019
making pain the 5th vital sign changed how often pain was documented (82% vs 31%) but it didn’t change the management of pain - alford amersa2019

let’s not perpetuate stigma by joking about people with suds lying & hiding things from physicians. amersa2019 1) this isn’t unique to suds. 2) we have talked about all the stigma still coming from the healthcare team. why would someone want to be open? we can do better.

since 2000, only 6% of all physicians have become waivered to prescribe buprenorphine. this is terrible. even if you are working to xthexwaiver it’s still important to get waivered so you can treat patients now! amersa2019
methadone is not a religion. it doesn’t matter if you believe in it, it is an evidence based treatment. it works - alford amersa2019

over 20yrs ago an institute of medicine report stated that we put too much emphasis on protecting the public from methadone rather than getting methadone to the people who need it. we still need to break down restrictive policies for methadone access - alford amersa2019

daniel alford discusses the 1st time he worked in a methadone clinic. it provided new insights into successes of methadone. working in the hospital, most physicians only see patients for whom methadone isn’t working & it skews their opinion on treatment efficiency amersa2019

we probably need a much better understanding of personality disorders in general before we can make general statements about which type of person wouldn’t benefits from psychedelic therapy. amersa2019
loved the audience question about whether psychedelics could be classed as performance enhancing drugs & how that should be addressed in this research & treatment neuroethics amersa2019

important audience question about the accessibility of psychedelic treatments. these studies are currently mainly accessed by middle class participants so there are major structural barriers that need to be overcome in these studies. amersa2019
it appears as though the affective components of nicotine withdrawal can be significantly diminished when people quit smoking after psilocybin treatment-  amersa2019
set & setting for psychedelic use is paramount. in the right setting it can result in major positive changes, but in the wrong setting it can worsen anxiety or depressive symptoms -  amersa2019
we need more funding for psychedelic research so that we can conduct rigorous trials to establish the best clinical model for use -  amersa2019

participants need to be able to relax & let go during a psilocybin session. this is necessary for the expansion of consciousness that brings about the mystical experiences that result in many of the important changes we have seen - cosimano amersa2019
anything and everything can come up in a psilocybin session & we need to be prepared to allow that to happen & ensure the participants feel safe - cosimano amersa2019
mary cosimano will now talk about her experiences working as a guide in psychedelic treatment studies. she as served as a guide for hundreds of people in these studies - amersa2019
when looking at a pilot study of psilocybin with cbt for smoking cessation  found over 80% of people were still abstinent after 6 months amersa2019
the nature of a person’s mystical experience while under the influence of psilocybin drove the changes in personality that have been seen -  amersa2019
psilocybin study was the first experimental study to demonstrate changes in a personality dimension. it increases levels of openness -  amersa2019
the risks of psychedelic use can be mitigated in research & medical settings so there is no reason not to consider them like other medications that can have bad side effects -  amersa2019

there are some harms & risks associated with psychedelic compounds: - harm in people with psychosis - a “bad trip” - moderate elevations in cardiovascular activity we know a lot about these known risks & we have ways to mitigate them in medicine -  amersa2019
next up is  to tell us more about the specific role of psychedelics in addiction treatment! amersa2019

for many drugs there seems to be a mismatch between their legal classification & the personal & social harms they can produce. alcohol & tobacco have highest rated harms but are legal. psilocybin has the lowest rated harms but is illegal - stauffer amersa2019

the initial clinical use of psychedelics ended as a result of the war on drugs in the 1970s. all psychedelics are still schedule 1 drugs in the usa & considered to have no clinical use - stauffer amersa2019
dr. christopher stauffer begins by giving us a brief history on psychedelics & their use in medicine amersa2019
time for the plenary panel on the use of psychedelics in addiction treatment! amersa2019
recognition that trauma is prevalent does not mean we have to push for disclosure. we can offer support & harm reduction interventions without any disclosure - elizabeth miller amersa2019

trauma screening tools only really benefit the people in the position of power. they send the message that resources will only be provided to people who are willing to share their shame - elizabeth miller amersa2019
screening lets healthcare professionals off the hook. we only provide resources to the people who disclose & the majority of people are not comfortable doing so - elizabeth miller amersa2019

health professionals have the privilege of being able to sit with survivors & validate their experiences. the most important request from survivors is to never push someone to disclose information or tell their story when they’re not ready - elizabeth miller amersa2019
we must remember that this is a country that was founded on genocide & slavery. we need to be aware of this system of oppression & collective trauma - elizabeth miller amersa2019
currently our focus on trauma care is on screening tools & this isn’t patient focused. we need to shift our focus. what matters most is what happens after the trauma - elizabeth miller amersa2019
dr. elizabeth miller is now talking about moving from trauma informed care to patient healing centered engagement. amersa2019

it can be incredibly healing when someone doesn’t try & talk you out of the shame, but instead just sits with you in that feeling. shame is irrational, we can’t talk people out of it - lynn sanford amersa2019

shame can be contagious. it is hard to sit with someone who is exposing shame & not feel defective ourselves about the areas of our own lives about which we are shameful. telling them “it’s okay” is a way to comfort ourselves, not them - lynn sanford amersa2019

when we try to work with people who have experienced trauma we often force them to have feelings in the presence of others. for many, this can be more of a problem than a solution - lynn sanford amersa2019

there is an important different between guilt and shame. guilt recognizes that good & bad can exist in the same person. it can promote change. shame is “i am a bad person” & is always a burden. it can be the “bobsled to hell”. - lynn sanford amersa2019

if you’re interested in the impact of opioid overdose prevention & response training in medical students  & the ways we are expanding on this & other addiction medicine training initiatives, come check out poster 86! amersa2019

if you want changes in your institution’s education & policies re: suds, any of us can push for those changes. at  , all med students will now graduate with naloxone training & bup-waivers. this happened due to med student initiatives & advocacy. amersa2019
interesting conversation at amersa2019 about how to help patients who never intend to use opioids but end up physically dependent on them due to contamination of other drugs.
dr. paula lum presents a really interesting case study on the potential use of naltrexone to prevent opioid overdose death in people who use methamphetamines amersa2019
due to increasing rates of fentanyl contamination in non-opioid drugs, we should recommend naloxone for anyone using any street drug - paula lum amersa2019
there is definitely still stigma from the healthcare team toward people who use drugs, but this has improved & it just takes one person in a department to initiate changes in attitudes -  amersa2019
prescribing buprenorphine is not optional. it is the evidence based treatment & physicians need to be offering this to patients -  amersa2019
we don’t send hyperglycemic patients away & say “too bad you ate that cake”, so there is no way we should send patients with oud away just becuase they used opioids recently -  amersa2019
everyone in the emergency department is taught how to use the screening & evaluation instruments for buprenorphine initiation. it should be everyone’s responsibility -  amersa2019

there a many required trainings that are part of being a physician, getting waiver training to prescribe buprenorphine is no different. all physicians should do it as part of their training -  amersa2019
perfection can be the enemy of the good. we don’t need everything to be perfect to implement these types of changes, we just need to get started -  amersa2019

important reminder from  that language matters. she urges amersa2019 attendees to remove phrase “medication assisted treatment” from their vocabulary. opioid agonist medications are treatments just like any other medication, there is nothing “assisted” about them.
offering opioid agonist treatment in the emergency department does not increase ed visits by people in need of treatment -  amersa2019

we know that treatment with opioid agonist treatments works but most people who could benefit do not receive it. we need to find ways to break down these barriers & get people access to treatment -  amersa2019
it’s important to begin by humanizing this conversation -  a great way to make sure that we are all focused on the most important aspect of the opioid crisis: the people who are affected. amersa2019
looking forward to hearing  betty ford award plenary session on how emergency departments can play a role in combatting the opioid crisis. amersa2019

fantastic audience question: when are we going to move on from the question of tapering or not to the question of how to manage a patient with complex pain & focus on the person with these problems? amersa2019
good advice from the moderator, dr. joanna starrels, for people asking questions at the amersa2019: try & focus on arguing with the ideas & not the individuals.
thank you for calling that out. that statement really bothered me too & seemed entirely unnecessary to the rest of her points.
when opioid tapers are done right, patients do not suffer harms. we need to make sure physicians engage in compassionate, careful opioid tapering -lembke amersa2019
although rates of opioid prescribing have decreased there is huge variability across the country. in alabama in 2017 there were 107 opioid prescriptions per 100 people! - lembke amersa2019
we are all motivated by mutually affectionate relationship. we want our patients to like us so it is much easier to prescribe patients opioids & & ignore the potential harms - lembke amersa2019
after 29 vaping deaths there was a cdc task force to investigate. there have been many more deaths associated with opioid tapering but there is still no investigation. -  amersa2019
many of the opioid policies are inconsistently applied & there is no accountability for patient outcomes for any agency making & mandating these polices -  amersa2019

important key policy insights from : 1. policy is never entirely rational 2. policy is made not by one but many people with different motivations this means policies can often be jarring & inconsistent. amersa2019
the next half of this debate will be on who should be making the laws & policies surrounding opioid dose re-education or discontinuation. amersa2019
there is currently no evidence that tapering is helpful. we must not lower our evidential standards in medicine due to moral concerns -  amersa2019
“what we have done is get our fingerprints of the bodies of these patients who overdose”  talking about the relationship between opioid tapering & increased overdose rates. amersa2019
starting statement from : no one is arguing that tapering is never helpful, the issue is whether it should be a general rule. amersa2019
dose & duration matter. the longer a person is on an opioid & the higher the dose, the more likely they are to develop an opioid use disorder - lembke amersa2019
important starting point from dr. lembke: tapering is not the same as abrupt discontinuation & she advocates slow, careful tapering. amersa2019
looking forward to the amersa2019 spicy debate on opioid tapering with  and dr. anna lembke!

last night i organized my stuff so i’d be ready to head to the airport after work to go to amersa2019. now one of my shoes is missing. i may be being paranoid but i think one of the cats took it so i couldn’t leave!

it's great that you're considering getting involved. i am not sure how active your school's chapter is but that's a great place to start.  is another good person to ask. she is very active in ama, was on the lgbtq standing committee & is now a delegate for glma.

there are so many problems that seem to be at the core of this. i have seen a few pharmacists on twitter working hard to improve these sorts of issues but there still seems to be a lot of misinformation.
i know others who have regular problems too so you are definitely not alone. today's debacle was a new problem & just especially frustrating since we had checked about the rules in advance.
i get that these rules & laws exist for a reason & i don't expect the pharmacists to break them but i don't understand how the rules are so inconsistent & so inconsistently applied.

today: p3: you can't pick it up unless is 2days before date it was last filled. that's the law. also p3: since you were told something different i can see if i can override it & give it to you today. *hands over script* are you happy now? how can rules be so inconsistent? (2/2)

getting a prescription should not take this much energy. pharmacist 1: you can pick it up 3 days before the date on prescription. p2 (yesterday): you can pick it up 3 days before the date on the prescription. come back tomorrow & we'll fill it. seems simple, right? (1/2)
i am so grateful to go to a med school that supports these efforts! well done on such a successful event team  and !
we have also added the naloxone-related risk compensation beliefs scale, which is again a little specific but might be helpful.
i have reached the point where i have so many pinned emails i need to deal with that i am seriously considering just opening a new email account & never looking back.
preparing to pack the overdose prevention & care kits to hand out this weekend with  students from ,  and detroit vs addiction!

it's no wonder many students feel like they don't belong in graduate programs or academia in general. exercises like this just reinforce the idea that if we were not always perfect then we will never be good enough. (3/3)

since undergrad i have done very well in my courses, presenting at conferences, published research, received grants & run my own small studies. shouldn't these things be more relevant to my f30 grant application? (2/3)

it has been almost a decade since i completed my bachelor's. i have worked full-time in research, completed a master's & was accepted into a md/phd program. why do i still have to justify grades i received during undergrad? (1/3)

many students involved in this event took part in the fantastic naloxone "train the trainer" workshop run by . students learned about the signs & risks of overdose & how to educate others. now we are going out into the community to put those skills to use!
everyone welcome  to twitter. she is a fellow medstudent & a fantastic advocate for patients and physicians!

a reminder that when someone doesn't respond to your text/email/call, most of the time it is a them-problem not you-problem. it is very unlikely that they are purposefully ignoring you for some reason.
happy birthday ! i hope you have a wonderful day!
i’ll be attending for the first time too! i have a poster on our new medical student opioid prevention and response training initiative.
i know people who have suffered severe withdrawal when stopping regular kratom use. obviously these cases are all anecdotal and i don't know the data on this but it is something to consider.
oscar doesn’t seem to care too much about my return from sfn19 but he really seems to love my new backpack from ⁦⁩!
i have not seen one before but i’ll ask around.
well that’s a wrap for sfn19 for me. i had a great time seeing old friends & meeting new people, plus learning about the cool science everyone is doing!
sadly i have to leave but sharing this in case anyone’s still around sfn19
you still have time! i think what makes this collection worse is that this was me attempting to be reasonable and only take stuff that would have a use.
initially i’d tried to collect the brains but tigger kept stealing them to play soccer. now they’re all filled with teeth holes so i figured i needed to update his collection.
oh, and the cats love the brains
some stuff like the coloring books friends asked for. the reusable bags we use all the time so hopefully i hve a lifetime supply now!

that was just sunday’s collection & i was trying not to take stuff i knew i wouldn’t use (like the plush toys & overized t-shirts). i’ve been a little more restrained since then b/c of the very real possibility that i wouldn’t be able carry all my stuff home.

i promised that i wouldn’t bring home more from sfn19 than i could fit in my suitcase... i’m not sure i am keeping that promise since this is only the swag from day 1. luckily i gained a backpack to carry the extra stuff!
how can we maximize the potential benefits of these technologies while minimizing the risks of misuse? our brains deserve special legal & ethical protections -  sfn19
we must be firmly committed to enabling these technologies to progress & allowing people access to them but we must have a clear ethical framework for this progress -  sfn19
we need to establish what it means to protect mental privacy & what it would mean to protect it. we must develop a more robust understanding of freedom of thought -  sfn19
there are currently no laws to prevent people from collecting our brain data and selling it to third parties -  sfn19
in a study by  they found that people rated their social security numbers as being more sensitive than their brain data. this is concerning! sfn19
we need to engage the international community to establish an ethical, socially responsible foundation for the way in which we alter the human brain -  sfn19

is there a use for neurotechnologies for moral enhancement? currently chemical castration is used for certain sexual offenders. it is possible that we could offer “moral enhancement” as alternatives to incarceration but should this be allowed? -  sfn19

in some primary schools in china students are required to wear eeg headsets to monitor their neural activity. these data transmit to teachers, parents, and the government. how will this impact their learning and creativity? -  sfn19
we have the genetic information non-discrimination act but we do not yet have any equivalent for neurological information -  sfn19
we have already made our peace with advertising companies manipulating our behavior but is there a line that shouldn’t be crossed? -  sfn19
people are inherently unreliable in their self reports so brain activity provides a more accurate representation. are we okay with marketing companies having this information? -  sfn19

privacy should not only be for the wealthy/elite. privacy must extend to all individuals across society, so we must ensure that everyone has the ability to say no to these neurotechnologies without risking their livelihood -  sfn19

one of the leading cause of vehicle accidents is drowsy driving. some cars already have driver assist technology designed to detect variations that occur in drowsy driving. are brain wave monitoring caps designed for this purpose really very different? -  sfn19
brain monitoring devices are making their way into the workplace to allow employers to track employees attention & fatigue. does this protect employee safety or infringe on their rights? -  sfn19

many companies are collecting biological data including brain data from their devices (eg apple watch). currently there are minimal regulations surrounding data these companies can collect & use, we need to establish guidelines for the use of these data -  sfn19

if someone is able to alter memory to minimize the effects of traumatic events, how is this balanced with societal need to bring justice? a person who has blocked consolidation of a traumatic memory may not be able to serve as a witness -  sfn19
is a student who takes cognitive enhancers before exams representing themselves as someone they are not? or do they have the right to alter their own memory in whatever way they choose? -  sfn19

in sports, the competition is a celebration of natural talent rather than enhanced talent so we can reasonably set rules about enhancement & cheating; however, it is unclear whether these same rules should apply to enhancement in our daily lives -  sfn19
should certain types of neurological information be filtered through a professional who can help us understand the results? -  sfn19

do we have a right to access the inner workings of our own brains through neurotechnologies? should others be able to access the data from these devices? we need to establish answers to these questions as we develop these technologies -  sfn19
good science is responsible science and we all have a duty to make sure that science moves forward in a way that benefits society -  sfn19
it’s time for the sfn19 david kopf lecture on neuroethics with  on the ethical, legal, and social issues of altering human brains.
and i’m creepily watching  at his booth

come say hi to me as i represent  neuroscience program at the final grad school fair of sfn19. actually, just talk to me. i’ve been talking at my poster for the past 4 hours so i want to hear someone else talk!
which sfn19 vendors have savory snacks? i did not plan my food well today!
stop by and say hi! i’m happy to talk about this work or some of the other projects i’m working on (i.e. neuromodulation in oud, opioid overdose education in medical schools, neuroethics) sfn19
you know you want to get up early tomorrow to see my poster at sfn19. i’ll be there bright and early at 8am, come find out how anxiety impacts the stress response in people with opioid use disorder!
every element of your grant application must serve a purpose. especially for training grants, if something doesn’t support your training or your research then it shouldn’t be in your grant. sfn19
time for the  early career symposium, which will look at nida funding opportunities for trainees and early career investigators sfn19

don’t ask someone to write/review something with a deadline <24hrs away especially when you had plenty of time to reach out to them earlier. it doesn’t matter if that person is faculty, a peer, or someone working for you just don’t do it!
i was meeting with nih people. i’m about to stop by and say hi!

when meeting someone new at a conference & talking about your work, ask that person about their background before you go into the details of your project. it’s a great way to get to know that person & make sure you are explaining your work appropriately. sfn19
don’t annoy the reviewer! sfn19 you can do this in a variety of ways: - having a hard to read application, - using tiny figures, - pushing the boundaries of what’s acceptable.
it is important to make sure you methods are both rigorous & reproducible. reproducibility is key - reed sfn19
some funding mechanisms may not accept clinical trials. make sure you know how the nih defines clinical trial & whether your proposed research falls in this category - reed sfn19
it seems obvious but make sure you read the funding announcement in detail. these will give you information about the review criteria & the type of science they’re interested in - bruce reed sfn19
always talk with a program officer as you’re developing your grant ideas. many of them are here at sfn19 so go make an appointment if you can!
time for a professional development workshop on optimizing nih grant applications sfn19
if anyone sees me in publishers row looking at books please yell at me. i do not have the self control to be around books! sfn19

pretty similar themes from speakers at the neuroethics social, their work is accepted but not necessarily embraced. often neuroethics work is more of a side project. how can we make a shift in neuroscience so that neuroethics is considered a key part of the work? sfn19
human brain organoids will always be primitive, reductionist models but they are the first & only experimental window into the development of the human brain, which is very exciting - arlotta sfn19
arlotta & sherwood developed human brain organoids with synapses that were both active and reactive to stimuli. sfn19

quadrato & arlotta have shown that organoids of certain brain cell types can grow & be kept alive for at least 4 years. this is amazing work but does bring with it a host of ethical questions that we need to consider. sfn19
the neuroinfomagical reusable cup is so good that my partner stole the one i got last sfn & it’s now his favorite mug. definitely worth completing the survey! sfn19

stick around tonight for the neuroethics social if you’re at sfn19. it will be a great opportunity to learn about how we can incorporate neuroethics into our neuroscience work & meet scientists who are already doing that!
really happy to see live closed captioning on the screens at the presidential lecture. definitely helping to improve accessibility! sfn19
if you’re at sfn19 here is where you can find gender neutral bathrooms.
time for the presidential special lecture on understanding cortical development & disease with paula arlotta sfn19
today’s unhelpful conference tip: bring a different pair of shoes for each day. your feet will still hurt but you’ll have new & different types of pain each day! sfn19
reminder to presenters & people asking questions. the microphones are there so everyone can hear you, please use them even if you think you can speak loudly. thank you! sfn19
an important message i’ve heard a few times already at sfn19: we need to remember to include patients in our research when possible. their insights & needs should be what guides our work.
check out ’s talk on synaptic maturation. it’s starting now & the walk to s401 will be an energizing work out after sitting through all the morning sessions! sfn19
this is a great point. people get home from conferences & have so much to catch up on. if you want to make a good impression you don’t want to add to their workload, wait a few days. sfn19
i’m going to be at the grad school fair from 12-2pm representing  translational neuroscience program. stop by and say hi! sfn19
one of the exhibitors is handing out bananas instead of candy. that’s a great idea! booth 1814 for anyone who still needs breakfast. sfn19
if you’re at the tpda session tonight at sfn19 come check out my poster (i43) on the role of anxiety & stress in learning for people with opioid use disorder.
i finally got a  sagittal brain pin so i have to show it off! get yours before they sell out at sfn19.
it took me 20mins to find the neuroethics posters at sfn19 and they were so hidden i almost missed them. we shouldn’t be hiding the ethics, it’s an important part of what we do!
it’s not bad to ask for help, whether it be in our work life or our home life - christina dalla sfn19
advice that sounds easy but can be very hard: demand what you’re worth! - jackson sfn19
you don’t always want mentors who make you feel good, you need people who push you - jones-london sfn19
don’t forget that you can be a mentor too, at any career stage. it is important to give back whenever we are able - vanhoven sfn19
miri vanhoven reminds us that it is important to seek out mentors, preferably multiple mentors so we can gain diverse perspectives. sfn19
kasey jackson on how she overcome imposter syndrome: stop telling yourself it’s luck when you succeed at something. it can’t be luck this many times, it is you & you deserve to be here. sfn19
michelle jones-london points out that a work/life balance is not very realistic b/c sometime you have to focus more on one than the other. instead, focus on healthy work/life integration. sfn19

if you’re interested in the impact of anxiety & stress on learning check out my poster! you have two chances to see it: the tpda poster session from 6:30-8:30pm tonight or poster y43 at 8am on tuesday! sfn19
took the morning off to eat my way around chicago so i could be refreshed for sfn19! now i am at my first session, a professional development seminar on how to thrive as a woman in neuroscience.
that’s a wrap for neuroethics2019. another fantastic  conference filled with wonderful people. for anyone at sfn19 please check out the neuroethics social on sunday evening!
thanks ! people at sfn19 can also check out the neuroethics2019 social on sunday evening!

a great message that has come out of many of the talks at neuroethics2019 is a reminder to be aware of how our findings may be interpreted & to consider whether there are meaningful changes that can be implemented as a result of our work.
if you’re attending sfn19 you should definitely check this out!
farah - we must be careful because for some people describing a biological basis for differences implies permanence & therefore hopelessness once these changes occur. neuroethics2019

martha farah points out that if we focus only on problems in the brain we distract from issues that society can fix such as poverty, lack of access to healthcare & education, systemic biases etc. neuroethics2019
and those squishy brains make fantastic cat toys too!
i will be there tomorrow afternoon, please don’t sell out before then!

great point from  at neuroethics2019 when talking about learning from & engaging with the public: we don’t have to measure everything. sometimes it can be just enough to hold a public event that people enjoy. we don’t always have to measure its impact.

david mohr talking about using digital technology for mental health at neuroethics2019 major concern is whether data can ever be deidentified. for 95% of the population it only takes 4 gps points to identify them!
when discussing disorders of consciousness we need to spend less time talking about whether a person is conscious & focus more on whether they can experience suffering -  neuroethics2019
if you’re interested in memory & a person’s right to have their memory altered, come check out my poster (44) at neuroethics2019!

before we ask whether an intervention works we must first establish what problem exactly we are trying to solve -  this is an important question not just for ethicists but for everyone doing research. neuroethics2019

great question from  about how neuro-interventions may perpetuate systemic racism, especially since people of color make up a large portion of incarcerated people in the us. how can we ensure these interventions won’t exacerbate this problem? neuroethics2019
thank you  for keeping great time for the panel & reminding the audience that questions should end in a “?” and ideally take under 60seconds to ask!neuroethics2019

really interesting session at neuroethics2019 about neuro-interventions for violent offenders. it may be possible to use non-invasive neuro-stimulation to alter aggression. should we be doing this? is there a risk that these interventions may become required for inmates?

happy to be back in chicago for neuroethics2019, the location of my first  meeting in 2015! just a warning to followers that the next week is going to be filled with tweets on neuroethics & then sfn19 so you might want to mute me.
i have been loving the photos of the twins but it is great to see tinycat again!
we left 2 hours late but are finally heading to chicago for  conference followed by sfn19. looking forward to seeing many of you soon!
you need at least one pair per day.
why is my desk always covered in crumbs?** **i ask as i eat my afternoon snacks of granola bars, rice cakes, and cereal.

i planned to get a lot done today, here's how my day has gone: work on grant...word turns everything to wingdings, crashes & refuses to open. work on posters due monday...powerpoint crashes. give microsoft a break & work on my qualtrics surveys...qualtrics website won't load.

my cats and i have a morning routine that requires me to get back into bed after i shower so we can snuggle. it has not been great for my productivity but there is just no way to say no.
oh yes, i would also be interested in seeing any successful recent f30/f31s please!

definitely. i call it a "deer in the headlights" kind of day. that feeling where you freeze up despite knowing you need to be all kinds of productive. it's very frustrating. i hope things get better tomorrow!
